N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. Tit. 12 §§ 349-2.3 - Therapist's decision regarding arbitration

State Regulations
(a) Upon receipt of a notice of objection
(form A-1), a therapist may request arbitration by notifying the chairman in
accordance with the following: (1)
if only
arbitration issues are raised, the request for arbitration shall be made within
60 days after receipt of the notice of objection (A-1); (2)
if there are issues requiring
adjudication by a Workers' Compensation Law Judge in addition to arbitration
issues, the request for arbitration shall be made within 60 days of the filing
of the decision in favor of the therapist; and
(3)
failure to make timely request for
arbitration shall be deemed a waiver of the right to arbitration. If the therapist wishes to arbitrate the bill, he or she
shall complete and sign the request for arbitration and forward it to the
medical registration section together with a check to the order of the

Chairman, Workers' Compensation Board, in the sum of $5 as a minimum
arbitration fee. Notwithstanding any provision in this section to the contrary, upon application of the therapist, the chairman may for good cause shown excuse
the therapist for the delay in filing the request for arbitration, and schedule
the disputed bill for arbitration. (b) Failure of the therapist to render a bill
to the employer or carrier within 90 days from the last day of the month in
which services were rendered shall be deemed to be a waiver of the right to
arbitrate the bill. Notwithstanding any provision in this section to the
contrary, upon application of the therapist, the chairman may for good cause
shown excuse the therapist for the delay in submitting such bill to the
carrier, and schedule the disputed bill for arbitration. Notes
